head.title: Why We Should Care About Antarctica

hedline.hl1: Why We Should Care About Antarctica

block.p: The oil spill off Antarctica resulting from the wreck of an Argentine supply ship (news story, Feb. 1) is the embodiment of a nightmare that has long haunted those who know and love the frozen continent.

Why should we care about this remote place, which few people alive today will visit? The question may be hard to answer until you visit Antarctica - until you see with your own eyes the magnificence of the land, breathe the incredibly clear air and watch the penguins, seals and birds in their natural habitat. We who truly care about Antarctica feel that we should preserve this wonderful continent for the beleaguered Earth people of future centuries. To them, our own crowded world of 1989 will seem a Garden of Eden in retrospect, and they will surely cherish an unspoiled refuge that will be far more accessible to them than to us.

There are other, urgent reasons why humankind is ill advised to despoil Antarctica. The continent lies at the hub of our planet's weather system, and the turbulent air above it acts as a giant pump that helps circulate air masses around the earth. It is also a clean lab - the best place for monitoring the overall condition of earth's air, for seeing what we are doing to our planet. And it is the last great repository of natural resources vanishing from the rest of the planet (consumed by our wasteful life style). Have we any right to gouge out these remaining minerals and fossil fuels in the smug assumption that future generations will have the technology to survive without them?

The future of Antarctica is partly a moral issue, and if this story has a sad ending, the responsibility will weigh heavily on the human conscience forever. ELEANOR C. EISENMENGER New York, Feb. 2, 1989
